DevOps practices encompass a range of methodologies that streamline the software development lifecycle by fostering collaboration between development and operations teams. <[silence]> Continuous Integration (CI) is a practice where developers frequently merge their code changes into a shared repository, triggering automated builds and tests. <[silence]> This approach minimizes integration issues and allows for rapid detection of defects. <[silence]> It emphasizes the importance of maintaining a codebase that is always in a deployable state. <[silence]>

Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is another pivotal practice within DevOps, which involves managing and provisioning computing infrastructure through machine-readable definition files, rather than physical hardware configuration or interactive configuration tools. <[silence]> This practice enables consistent and repeatable infrastructure setups, reducing the risk of human error. <[silence]> Tools such as Terraform and Ansible are commonly used to implement IaC, allowing teams to version control infrastructure changes alongside application code. <[silence]>

Automated Testing is integral to DevOps, ensuring that code changes do not introduce new bugs or regressions. <[silence]> By automating the testing process, teams can quickly validate the functionality of their applications and receive immediate feedback. <[silence]> This practice supports the rapid iteration and deployment of software, aligning with the agile principles of DevOps. <[silence]> Test automation frameworks like Selenium and JUnit are frequently employed to facilitate this process. <[silence]>
